metadata.case_name: Appellant (representative of Purshottamdas) v. Respondents (Dhanrupmal and legal representatives of Motilal)

facts.text: The property mortgaged was a four-roomed shop with certain appurtenances, standing on a piece of land measuring 5 yards by 15 yards in Naya Bazar, Ajmere.

Mortgage dated August 1, 1899 created by Purshottamdas (now dead) in favour of Dhanrupmal (respondent) for Rs. 6,300 of which Rs. 5,750 left with mortgagee to redeem a prior mortgage on the same and another property.

Mortgage instrument provided that on redemption of prior mortgage, possession of shop to be taken by Dhanrupmal who would appropriate rent in lieu of interest; possession of other property (share in Kacheri) to be made over to mortgagor Purshottamdas.

Provisions: Mortgagor or heirs not entitled to redeem for 85 years. After expiry of 85 years, redeem within 6 months; if not, no claim over property, mortgagee no claim to money or lagat (repairs), deed deemed sale deed. No need for fresh sale deed. Expenses on repairs/new constructions paid on redemption per mortgagee's account.
Dhanrupmal redeemed prior mortgage, took possession of shop, delivered Kacheri possession to mortgagor.
Dhanrupmal assigned rights under mortgage to Motilal on April 12, 1939; Motilal died, estate represented by sons (respondents).
Estate of Purshottamdas represented by his son, the appellant.
Appellant filed suit for redemption on January 2, 1947 in Court of Sub-Judge 1st Class, Ajmer (Civil Suit No. I of 1947) against respondents.
Respondents contested suit as premature, no right of redemption till August 1, 1984 (85 years from mortgage).

Sub-Judge held 85-year postponement invalid as clog on equity of redemption, passed preliminary decree for redemption (judgment/decree March 30, 1948), following decision of Judicial Commissioner, Ajmer.
Judicial Commissioner, Ajmer, on appeal (Civil First Appeal No. 13 of 1948), distinguished prior decision, held provision not a clog, allowed appeal, dismissed suit (judgment/decree March 21, 1950).
Suit for redemption brought over 47 years after mortgage date.
Case governed by Transfer of Property Act.

legal_issues.text: Whether the covenant postponing redemption for 85 years, along with 6-month redemption window thereafter, amounts to a clog on the equity of redemption, rendering the suit not premature.
Whether the term fixing mortgage term at 85 years is invalid as oppressive or unconscionable.

petitioner_arguments.text: The covenant creating long term of 85 years for mortgage, taken with provision to redeem within 6 months thereafter or not at all, other terms, and circumstances, is a clog on equity of redemption; thus mortgage money due all along, suit not premature.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Section 60 Transfer of Property Act; rule against clogs on equity of redemption

petitioner_arguments.text: Term that mortgage not redeemable for 85 years amounts to clog.

Mortgagee free to demand payment anytime while mortgagor cannot redeem for 85 years; mortgagee can spend unlimited on repairs/constructions, mortgagor pays per mortgagee's account; all terms benefit mortgagee.
Prior mortgage indicates mortgagor's impecunious position.

respondent_arguments.text: Suit premature as no right of redemption for 85 years after mortgage date, till August 1, 1984.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Section 60 Transfer of Property Act; Bakhtawain Begum v. Husaini Khanam

respondent_arguments.text: Suit brought as price of land gone up post-war.

court_reasoning.text: Term providing failure to redeem within 6 months deems deed sale and takes away right to redeem is invalid; once a mortgage always a mortgage, right to redeem cannot be taken away (s.60 TPA).
court_reasoning.key_observation: This term ignored; right to redeem continues even after 6 months.

court_reasoning.text: 85-year term fixes when principal becomes due (right to redeem accrues); does not take away right, merely postpones accrual. Parties free to contract on when principal due.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Not a clog in sense of taking away right.

court_reasoning.text: Equity relieves against unconscionable bargains where lender takes advantage of mortgagor's necessity/embarrassment. No evidence of oppression here: long terms common in India; prior mortgage freed Kacheri; mortgage money more but smaller security; no high interest complaint; suit after 47 years; small property limits repairs.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Bargain fair, between equals; no unconscionability.

court_reasoning.text: No provision for mortgagee to demand money anytime; rights co-extensive. Repairs clause for necessary repairs only, per account as safeguard. Not all terms benefit mortgagee.
Suit premature as term not expired.

holdings.text: Provision deeming deed sale on failure to redeem within 6 months after 85 years invalid as clog on equity of redemption.
85-year term valid, not a clog; no unconscionability; principal not due till then, right to redeem not accrued.

precedents_cited.relevance: Right to redeem arises after term expires unless special condition; ordinarily only on expiration of specified period.
Principle: Mortgage security redeemable notwithstanding contrary provision; any clog void; once a mortgage always a mortgage.

precedents_cited.case_name: Mohammad Sher Khan v. Seth Swami Dayal
precedents_cited.relevance: Once right to redeem arises under s.60 TPA, cannot be taken away; unqualified terms.
Equity jealous of securities converting to purchases; relieves necessitous men from crafty impositions.

precedents_cited.case_name: G. and C. Kreglinger v. New Patagonia Meat and Cold Storage Company Ltd.
precedents_cited.relevance: Equity relieves against penalties; origin in common law mortgage hardships; interferes only on unconscientious conduct; ascertain real nature as mortgage.

statutes_cited.name: Transfer of Property Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Mortgagor right to redeem after principal due; unqualified, right continues once arisen, cannot be contracted away.

outcome.summary: Appeal dismissed; suit for redemption held premature as 85-year term valid and not expired; 6-month forfeiture clause severed as invalid but does not affect term.

key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core principle against clogs on equity of redemption.

key_quotes.text: The rule against clogs on the equity of redemption is that, a mortgage shall always be redeemable and a mortgagors right to redeem shall neither be taken away nor be limited by any contract between the parties.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: The reason then justifying the Courts power to relieve a mortgagor from the effects of his bargain is its want of conscience.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Limits equity relief to unconscionable bargains.
